p: The habitat is characterized by high productivity owing to its upwelling system [ 45]. Alongshore wind stress brings cool, nutrient-rich water to the surface [ 9]. In such upwelling systems, small pelagic reproduction has been found to depend mainly on two factors: retention of larvae and primary productivity. Both are influenced by wind conditions [ 32, 46– 51]. On the one hand, according to Thiaw et al. [ 34], the lagged spring and autumn upwelling indexes have a significant positive effect on Sardinella aurita abundance, because they spur primary productivity. On the other hand, wind stress can influence retention negatively, because larvae drift off to areas where they cannot survive [ 49, 52]. Owing to the broad continental shelf in the main spawning area, retention is high in general [ 48]. We use the ERA Interim Reanalysis product, available from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts [ 53], to calculate a seasonal coastal upwelling index (CUI) from wind stress using standard procedures [ 9] (see Section B of the S1 File). We average over the area between 13.5–16°N and 17.25–18°W. Our index shows the typical regional pattern: upwelling is strongest in winter, and subsides between June and October.
